Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  n/a
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob was great!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It felt like there was a bit of a disconnect between the more conceptual ideas taught in class and some of the expectations for the problem sets...i spent a lot of time going in the wrong direction on some of the questions, and wouldn't have understood others without going to office hours. Both Eli and Rob were generous with help, however.

This class was a great way of understanding how contemporary literature attempts to assign value to nature as capital. It provides a deep understanding of analytical methods and spreadsheet tools, and helps to improve command of Excel. It forces you to think in a new way about analyzing our environment in useful, policy-relevant ways.
The syllabus did not flow logically - the difficult concepts could have used much more lecture time, whereas too much time was dedicated to demonstration and discussion.

The class is very helpful, but focuses too much on the nitty gritty math. I think the class could be improved if more conceptual context was provided. This class is excellent for MESC students who want to do research on environmental economics, but could reach more students if it wasn't so math focused.
This was a challenging class, but eye-opening and very rewarding.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Getting some of the intuition down for how natural capital is measured, and how different management approaches change optimal resource use. Very helpful professor and TA.
Format was very interactive. Both Eli and Rob were very approachable and willing to help.
big-picture applications, class discussions

The enthusiasm of the students, the diversity of problems, and Eli's ability to parse through very difficult math and make it digestible. I was always hankering for more difficult or advanced problems because of how easily it all came.
Lectures and discussions were great. Prof. Fenichel is lively, and is great about addressing students' questions and curiosities.
The course was awesome and fills a much needed gap in the FES curriculum.
Professor Fenichel responds well to students and is very encouraging when the material is difficult.

Eli's ability to draw out the fundamental questions posed by natural resource economics (grounded in a strong understanding of natural science) as well as those areas where there is room to question traditional valuation.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course sometimes felt a little disorganized in connecting lecture and problem sets, and in distinguishing between less critical concepts that wouldn't be discussed again and more critical concepts that would pop back up in a few weeks.
Either lighter or more dispersed work load-- many assignments, exams, etc. came all at once at the end of the semester.
Clarity of the written problem set/midterm/final questions. Sometimes they weren't full sentences...
The 'fishing for beans' and 'climate chairs' exercises were a bit unnecessary (though fun). I think we could have gotten into some more 'meaty' material instead.
Syllabus and scheduling.
The problem sets essentially require hours of office hour help. I would rather have had weekly assignments that help cement the information than such long, difficult homeworks.
Connecting class lectures largely grounded in calculus to real world examples. I think the big picture was clear, but sometimes individual classes felt too theoretical.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
n/a

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob was always willing to assist with problem sets, exam preparation, questions about readings, etc. Feedback was quick. Grading was fair.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Very clear on explanations, expectations, and grading. Also makes himself easily available
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  He knows Excel so well. And he knows the math too. Fetter is a solid TA.

Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob was very responsive and helpful. He was always well-versed on the material, homework questions, etc., and able to explain things in new ways that helped cement lecture material.
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  A bit more clarity on the material covered
Instructor: Theodore Robert Fetter  Rob was an incredibly dedicated, responsive, and thoughtful teaching assistant. This course would have been much more difficult without his support.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided essential tools for a modeling project I will be undertaking as part of my MESc thesis on modeling sea level rise impacts to energy infrastructure.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get a better understanding of how to integrate resource protection into economic discussions.

Because AMES, Eli's first course, was so good that I had to fit this in. Plus, learning optimization techniques can be applied to so many things (e.g. I did my final project on solar management, using techniques developed for harvesting trees!)
I took Eli's Applied Math course in the Fall and really liked the set up and content, and trusted this would be a similarly valuable course. I was not let down.
I want to learn more environmental economics. I wish the class focused less on the math to how I could apply the valuation of natural capital in my future job.
A friend was taking it, checked it out

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Yes! Awesomely so.
Yes, and then some.
Not really. I wanted more conceptual understanding. I feel the information I learned would be excellent if I wanted to build models myself, but not as helpful for decision makers.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Plus: having someone else to do some of the work.Minus: having to deal with someone else when explaining how to do the work.
I enjoyed the group project.
Advantage: learn from others, new ideas, less writing per personDisadvantages: need to sort out differences, time investment organizing meetings, etc.
Yes, above and beyond.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Have some calculus/Be ready to set time aside for office hours
Take it!
Take it.
Take it
Take the prerequisites seriously
Make sure to take Fenichel's other math class first.
If you are comfortable with math, or are willing to sacrifice some good hours, do it.
Know calculus (or figure it out quickly if you're feeling rusty).
